Create a spring animation based on the current query.
Energy is provided via stock values, or custom energy or damping
between 0 and 1.
Lower energy values (higher damping), provide smooth deceleration
and no oscillation.
Higher energy values (lower damping) provide fast acceleration
and high oscillation.
Follow this call with optional “completion()” method

NOTE: total duration includes spring behavior - i.e. any exaggerated
or lengthened oscillation will take up part of the overall duration
such that the remaining animation will be shorter by comparison.

and timing curve.
To prevent sublayer animation pass “layerSupport:false”.
NOTE: the timing curve (for sublayer animations) will be linear
which may cause a perceptible discrepancy with the spring animation.

Perform rounding of this object’s corner angles
using a radius in points. Excess rounding will cause
the corners to “invert” or other side effects with
complex paths (sometimes noticable during animation).
WARNING: Attempts to animate a path change where corner
rounding exists has a medium probability of path distortion
during animation because Core Animation will not be able
to determine the correct points to interpolate between.
However, animating corner rounding (from one radius to
another) where no other path change occurs has a much
higher probability of succeeding without distortion.

each item. Optionally use this with a guard in the completion
handler to cause the completion logic to fire at a specific point
in the phasing.

Emanate the queried items along an axis, with the items emanating
outward from a relative (percentage-based) or absolute (point-based)
“anchor” position within the group of items.
The default anchor is 50% which emanates from the group’s center.
For example, if items total width is 500.0, specifying a relative
anchor of 50% will result in items “emanating” outward from 250.0
points from the leading edge of the item group (the group’s center,
in this case).
NOTE: Emanating from the outer edge (e.g. anchor at 0% or 100%) is
similar to “link()” with one important caveat: whereas “link” starts
exactly from the edge, “emanate” starts from the item position which
is offset from the edge.
Similar to “link()”, this method requires that the items – or for
single-axis emanation, the first item – has already been positioned
(within it’s container or relative to a reference item).

of items

items will be visible).

Emanate the queried items outward on the vertical axis from a
relative (percentage-based) or absolute (point-based) “anchor”
position within the group of items.
The default anchor is 50% which emanates from the group’s center.
For example, if items total height is 500.0, specifying a relative
anchor of 50% will result in items “emanating” outward from 250.0
points from the top edge of the item group (the group’s center,
in this case).
NOTE: Emanating from the outer edge (e.g. anchor at 0% or 100%) is
similar to “link()” with one important caveat: whereas “link” starts
exactly from the edge, “emanate” starts from the item position which
is offset from the edge.

“Flattening” a shape involves merging the shape with
any sublayers that may exist (respecting fill rule),
restoring fill color, stroke color, line width and dash
pattern (as applicable), shadows, removing sub layer add-ons
such as shape gradients, shape tile layers, shape fills,
custom strokes, etc, and finally marking the item as “flat”
so that subsequent mutations will only apply to the available
shape layer API and prevent further sub layer customizations.

Provide linearity to adjust which edge is used for positioning.
Default is .max edge (basically end-to-end). Change this to .mid
for items to overlap from their mid point or to .min to make

Optionally provide custom alignment to force the flowed items

from the progression’s edge. The custom alignment can further
take a custom axis for the alignment (if other than the axis
of the progression) and in the case of “justified” alignment
how to handle the alignment of last “line”.
NOTE: using a custom axis on alignments (especially with axis “both)
when the items are of diverse sizes will give indeterminate results.

Emanate the queried items outward on the horizontal axis from a
relative (percentage-based) or absolute (point-based) “anchor”
position within the group of items.
The default anchor is 50% which emanates from the group’s center.
For example, if items total width is 500.0, specifying a relative
anchor of 50% will result in items “emanating” outward from 250.0
points from the leading edge of the item group (the group’s center,
in this case).
NOTE: Emanating from the outer edge (e.g. anchor at 0% or 100%) is
similar to “link()” with one important caveat: whereas “link” starts
exactly from the edge, “emanate” starts from the item position which
is offset from the edge.
Similar to “link()”, this method requires that the items – or at a

Providing one quadrantal will align both items and anchor on that
quadrantal position. Providing an additional anchor quadrantal will
align the item quadrantal (at that quadrantal position) to the anchor
quadrantal (at that quadrantal position).
For example, align(.A2) will align the .A2 position of each item to
the .A2 position of the anchor item.
Wheras, align(.A2, with:.C3) will align the .A2 position of each item
to the .C3 position (center) of the anchor item.

origin

a hashable value to logically group the items for emanation on the

Apply glow to the item(s) including views, layers, shapes
or text layers.
Mutator options (such as .random) affect “offset”.
Specify “masked” to support transparent or semi-transparent
item(s) with the masked glow being knocked out of the item(s).
Specify “maskColor” to be applied to the masked area of the
glow. If “masked” and “maskColor” are specified together
the mask color can help make mask edge artifacts less visible and
in case of complex shapes – to fill in the parts of the glow
mask that do not get knocked out properly – so that the masked
area blends with the background better. If “maskColor” is
specified on it’s own then it will provide a color fill that
occupies the shape of the item(s).
NOTE: If item(s) already have layer addons, or transform/alpha
are applied, or “masked” == true, or “maskColor” is specified,
then the glow will be represented as a Layer Addon which
can then be animated independent of the item(s).
NOTE: For applying glows to text see also TextShape object which
can better represent glows (as a shape) than TextLayers can.

relative to point size so remains consistent across sizes.
Optionally provide point size that spacing calculation

NOTE: CATextLayer supports letter spacing.

axes to get a percentage of the average between the
container height and width.)

Perform smoothing of this query of shape(s) by a degree of
precision with “precision” 0 making an extremely
smoothed/rounded shape (like a water-worn rock), with
“precision” 1 (default) providing a typical smoothing,
“precision” 2 or more providing corner rounding.
Note: the slope of the rounding depends on the length
between the points, with greater lengths causing a more
gradual slope before the join points. This is most
noticeable with the default precision of 1. This “effect”
allows “smooth” method to potentially provide more
“organic” corner rounding than “roundedCorners” does.
WARNING: Attempts to animate smoothing (from one precision
to another or some other path change where smoothing exists)
has a high probability of path distortion during animation
because Core Animation will not be able to determine the
correct points to interpolate between. Try using
instead if you will only be animating
the corner change.
NOTE: Prefer initializing shape via
method
directly on the shape itself and reserve this method
for dynamic updates.
